intro: Taxus canadensis var. floridana, commonly known as the Florida yew, is a rare and endangered plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a slow-growing evergreen shrub or small tree with dark green, needle-like leaves that are arranged in spirals along the stems. The plant produces small, reddish-purple berries that are toxic to humans and animals. Its botanical features include a thick, scaly bark and a dense, compact growth habit. This species is characterized by its ability to thrive in moist, acidic soils and partial to full shade.
